summary: The document is a comprehensive collection of personnel and administrative records detailing the career of William P. Burke, Jr., within the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). It spans from the 1940s to the 1960s, covering his roles, including Chief of the New Orleans Field Office, his commendations, such as the Intelligence Medal of Merit, and his retirement. The records include efficiency ratings, promotion recommendations, security clearance processes, and letters of appreciation, highlighting Burke's significant contributions to intelligence collection and administration.
key_findings: William P. Burke, Jr. served as the Chief of the New Orleans Field Office from its inception in 1947 until his retirement.
Awarded the Intelligence Medal of Merit for outstanding service, particularly for developing programs that produced important intelligence information.
Performance evaluations consistently praised his thorough knowledge, conservative nature, and legalistic approach.
Received favorable evaluations and commendations for integrity, high standards, and ability to secure cooperation.
Recommended for promotion based on outstanding performance despite not meeting the usual time-in-grade requirement.
Had a distinguished educational background and served honorably in the U.S. Marine Corps during World War II.
Letters from senior officials, including John A. McCone, Director of the CIA, commended his faithful and loyal service.
